Literature Review: Retinal degeneration, a leading cause of vision loss worldwide, presents a significant challenge in the field of ophthalmology. The mammalian retina, being a postmitotic neural tissue, lacks the capacity for endogenous regeneration, making cell replacement therapies an attractive avenue for potential treatment. This literature review aims to explore the factors affecting stem cell-based regenerative approaches in retinal degeneration, focusing on cell delivery challenges, the role of the recipient immunological microenvironment, and issues related to connectivity between transplanted cells and host circuitry.The advent of human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs) and induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) has revolutionized the field of regenerative medicine, offering new possibilities for treating retinal degenerative diseases. Takahashi et al. (2007) demonstrated the generation of iPSCs from adult human fibroblasts, opening up new avenues for patient-specific cell therapies. This breakthrough has been particularly significant in the context of retinal regeneration, as it allows for the development of autologous cell replacement strategies, potentially circumventing immune rejection issues.One of the primary challenges in stem cell-based therapies for retinal degeneration is the efficient delivery and integration of transplanted cells. Zarbin et al. (2019) reviewed various cell delivery methods, including subretinal injection and cell sheet transplantation, highlighting the importance of optimizing these techniques to ensure cell survival and integration. The authors emphasized the need for minimally invasive approaches to reduce surgical trauma and enhance transplant outcomes.The development of three-dimensional organoid culture systems has been a game-changer in retinal regeneration research. Kuwahara et al. (2015) demonstrated the generation of self-organizing optic cups from human embryonic stem cells, recapitulating key aspects of human retinal development in vitro. These organoids provide a valuable tool for studying retinal development, disease modeling, and drug screening, as well as a potential source of cells for transplantation.The recipient immunological microenvironment plays a crucial role in the success of cell replacement therapies. Zhao et al. (2016) investigated the immune response to subretinal allogeneic iPSC-derived retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) transplants in non-human primates. Their findings highlighted the importance of considering the immune privilege status of the subretinal space and the potential need for immunosuppression in allogeneic transplantation.The retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) has been a primary target for cell replacement strategies due to its critical role in supporting photoreceptor function. Kamao et al. (2014) reported the successful transplantation of iPSC-derived RPE cell sheets in a primate model of retinal degeneration, demonstrating the feasibility of this approach. However, challenges remain in ensuring long-term survival and functionality of transplanted RPE cells.Photoreceptor replacement represents another promising avenue for treating retinal degeneration. Barnea-Cramer et al. (2016) demonstrated the feasibility of generating transplantable photoreceptor precursors from human embryonic stem cells. The authors highlighted the importance of identifying the optimal developmental stage for transplantation to maximize cell integration and functional recovery.One of the most significant challenges in retinal cell replacement therapies is establishing functional connectivity between transplanted cells and the host retinal circuitry. Gagliardi et al. (2019) reviewed the current understanding of synaptic integration of transplanted photoreceptors and the factors influencing this process. The authors emphasized the need for further research into the mechanisms of synaptic rewiring and the development of strategies to enhance functional integration.The potential of stem cell-based therapies extends beyond photoreceptor and RPE replacement. Venugopalan et al. (2016) explored the possibility of replacing retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) in glaucoma using stem cell-derived RGCs. This approach faces additional challenges related to axon guidance and establishing long-distance connections with central targets in the brain.Despite the promising advances in stem cell-based approaches for retinal regeneration, several hurdles remain. Zarbin et al. (2020) provided a comprehensive review of the challenges and potential solutions in translating stem cell therapies for retinal diseases to the clinic. The authors highlighted the importance of addressing issues such as tumorigenicity, immune rejection, and long-term safety and efficacy in clinical trials.In conclusion, stem cell-based regenerative approaches hold great promise for treating retinal degeneration. However, successful implementation of these therapies requires overcoming challenges related to cell delivery, immune responses, and functional integration. Future research should focus on optimizing transplantation techniques, understanding and modulating the recipient immune microenvironment, and developing strategies to enhance synaptic connectivity between transplanted cells and host circuitry. As the field continues to advance, interdisciplinary collaboration and rigorous preclinical and clinical studies will be crucial in translating these promising therapies into effective treatments for patients with retinal degenerative diseases.
